cell.notes: ‘Seekoei’ directly translated is hippopotamus

cell.speaker: Hendrik
cell.eng: OS (Hendrik): You must actually in your ...

cell.speaker: Hendrik
cell.afr: Jy moet nou eintlik op jou...

cell.speaker: Hendrik
cell.eng: OS (Hendrik): No young-one (term of endearment) first wait.

cell.speaker: Bab
cell.eng: Bab: This is Griet Seekoei, who speaks here.

cell.speaker: Bab
cell.nuu: Griet Seekoei ke a he ǂxoa ng a.

cell.notes: N|uu Levi transcribed and translated. Bonny updated. Alena updated.

cell.speaker: Antjie
cell.eng: Antjie: My name is Anna Kassie. My small-name

cell.speaker: Antjie
cell.nuu: Ng ka |î ke ng Anna Kassie.g ka |î ǂ’î,

cell.notes: N|uu Levi transcribed and translated

cell.eng: Subject: The Language Rosedale, Upington, A. Kassie, G. Seekoei

cell.notes: Subject: The Language Rosedale, Upington, A. Kassie, G. Seekoei

AFRIKAANS/KHOEKHOEGOWAB/N|UU TRANSCRIPTION
Bonny updated: ʘû ndi replaces pondi.
N|uu Levi transcribed and translated. Bonny updated. Alena updated

cell.speaker: Antjie
cell.eng: Antjie: That is the reason I spoke to him. Don’t you see him sit, and look at me?
This is why I spoke a little so that they can understand me.

cell.speaker: Antjie
cell.nuu: Kea gai ke na ǂxoa k a ha. | ||u si |î n||!u a soo, a ha ǂaqe ng? Kea gai ke ng ǂxoa ng ku uu ||a.

cell.notes: N|uu Levi transcribed and translated. Bonny updated. Alena updated.

cell.speaker: Hendrik
cell.eng: OS (Hendrik): Now my name is again….

cell.notes: Khoekhoegowab transcribed and translated by Niklaas Fredericks

cell.speaker: Bab
cell.afr: Wag jy eers, wag jy eers.

cell.speaker: Antjie
cell.eng: Antjie: Me? I said now that my big-name is Anna Kassie and my small-name is Antjie.

cell.speaker: Antjie
cell.afr: My? Ek het nou gesê my grootnaam is Anna Kassie en my kleinnaam is Antjie.

cell.speaker: Bab
cell.eng: Bab: Yes, and my small-name is Babatjies.

cell.speaker: Bab
cell.afr: Ja, en my klein nametjie is Babatjies.

cell.notes: Babatjies in Afrikaans means little baby

cell.speaker: Subject
cell.eng: Subject: The Language Rosedale, Upington, A. Kassie, G. Seekoei

cell.notes: Subject: The Language Rosedale, Upington, A. Kassie, G. Seekoei

AFRIKAANS/KHOEKHOEGOWAB/N|UU TRANSCRIPTION

cell.speaker: Bab
cell.eng: Bab: They have to speak here now.
cell.speaker: Antjie
cell.eng: Antjie: He has to speak, he has to speak.

cell.nuu: : Kin ke ǂxoa ng k a.

cell.notes: N|uu Levi transcribed and translated. Bonny updated. Alena updated

cell.speaker: Nigel Crawhall
cell.eng: OS (Nigel Crawhall): Just ask about the clothing

cell.speaker: Tony
cell.eng: OS (Tony): Now we ask again about the (woman’s animal skin skirt) and the (man’s loincloth that goes through his legs and then between his buttocks)- will you please tell us again

cell.speaker: Tony
cell.afr: Nou ja, ons vra weer van dieen die,ons vra dit, sal julle ons weer vertel asseblief

cell.notes: N|uu Kerry transcribed and translated. Bonny note: he actually mispronounced !uu as g!uu, ǂ'haqbe as nǂaqbe

cell.speaker: Antjie
cell.eng: Antjie: […] You should say. We told them already then.
The man wears a man’s traditional loincloth […].He puts it onto his buttocks and ties it around. He puts in his penis, penis. He puts in his penis. And the woman, […] and the woman wearsa

cell.speaker: Antjie
cell.nuu: [...] n||aka dji ki ke ngdjDj [...]ǂâ u [...] e eei,[...] ei[...]
i x ku a ike. i xe ka ǂo ha haǂ’haqbeHa ku |’eha ||’ngke ǂâuke. Ha ||’ng k ǁû, ǁû. Ha ||’ng ke ǁû.A |ekA |ek ha si|au !uu.

cell.notes: N|uu Levi transcribed and translated. Bonny updated. n||aka is 'when'. [...] is too fast for to transcribe or is a false start. ǂâ u- might be spelled gǂâ u here. Alena updated

cell.speaker: Bab
cell.eng: Bab: Her breast will just stay naked on her chest.

cell.notes: N|uu Levi transcribed and

AFRIKAANS/KHOEKHOEGOWAB/N|UU TRANSCRIPTION

cell.speaker: Antjie
cell.eng: The woman wears an animal skin skirt, her breasts hang out, they are ugly.
Keep quiet, keep quiet! Get out, sit there and speak! You have drunk. Stand up and go!

cell.speaker: Antjie
cell.nuu: ke |a i ||hâikeA |eki ke |aua !uu n|a ke ||i ǂha kama ku n|a kin n||a.
|uda, |uda! A ||’ng kua si sûi n ǂxoa. A a kx’â. Khu||’âa ka !’û.

cell.notes: translated. Bonny updated. Alena updated. N|uu transcribed and translated by Ouma Geelmeid, Griet, Ouma Anna Koper, Claudia and Kerry. Alena updated. N|uu Levi transcribed and translated. Alena updated.

cell.speaker: Nigel
cell.eng: OS (Nigel): What is the difference between what the men wore and what the women wore?

cell.speaker: Nigel
cell.afr: Was daar ʼn verskil tussen wat die manne het aangetrek het en wat die vrouens het aangetrek?

cell.speaker: Antjie and Bab
cell.eng: Antjie and Bab: Yes,man’s traditional loincloth.

cell.notes: N|uu Levi transcribed and translated. Bonny updated.

cell.speaker: Bab
cell.eng: Bab: The man wears the man’s traditional loincloth.

cell.notes: N|uu Kerry transcribed and translated

cell.speaker: Antjie
cell.eng: Antjie: Man wearsman’s traditional loincloth.The woman wearstraditional

cell.notes: N|uu Levi transcribed and translated. Bonny updated.

cell.speaker: Hendrik
cell.eng: OS (Hendrik): A woman wears a traditional woman’s apron.

cell.notes: N|uu Kerry transcribed and translated

cell.eng: Subject: The Language Rosedale, Upington, A. Kassie, G. Seekoei

AFRIKAANS/KHOEKHOEGOWAB/N|UU TRANSCRIPTION

cell.speaker: Hendrik
cell.eng: OS (Hendrik): The woman wears a traditional woman’s apron.

cell.notes: N|uu Kerry transcribed and translated

cell.speaker: Tony
cell.eng: OS (Tony): What about the things they put on their heads?

cell.speaker: Tony
cell.afr: Wat van die dinge wat hulle op hulle koppe gesit het?

cell.speaker: Antjie
cell.eng: Antjie: It is”, it was surelyman, it wasIt wasman.
cell.speaker: Bab
Antjie
cell.eng: Antjie: Buttons, are those we put to keep on the that is the reason why theget fixed to the head, to the head, to the head.

cell.nuu: : Ki a ki |hare. |hare ke . |Hare ke, , |hare ke .
cell.speaker: Bab
cell.nuu: : Kunube ke mos i ka |i |hare, ke a gao |hare ki a !i || ng ku n|aa. Ku |aa, ku n|aa.

cell.notes: N|uu Levi transcribed and translated. Bonny note: |nâ 'head' has a long vowel; the community might prefer to spell this n|â or n|ââ, though, as they wish. Bonny updated some but can't confirm it all. (u ~ o before a nasal, so konobe would be a possible spelling). Alena updated.

cell.speaker: Tony
cell.eng: OS (Tony): Is there a difference between the thing that a woman...

cell.speaker: Tony
cell.afr: Is daar ʼn verskil tussen die ding wat ʼn vrou...

cell.speaker: Antjie
cell.eng: Antjie: It’s , it’s , it’s (animal skin head band with buttons that you put around your head.)

cell.notes: N|uu transcribed and translated by Ouma Geelmeid, Griet, Ouma Anna Koper, Claudia and Kerry.

cell.speaker: Tony
cell.eng: OS (Tony): Is it … just say again? What is it?

cell.speaker: Tony
cell.afr: Is dit … sê net weer … is dit? Wat is dit?

cell.notes: N|uu Kerry transcribed and translated

cell.eng: Subject: The Language Rosedale, Upington, A. Kassie, G. Seekoei

AFRIKAANS/KHOEKHOEGOWAB/N|UU TRANSCRIPTION

cell.speaker: Tony
cell.eng: OS (Tony): Is it the same thing for a man and a woman?

cell.speaker: Tony
cell.afr: Is dit nou dieselfde ding vir ʼn man en ʼn vrou?

cell.speaker: Antjie
cell.eng: Antjie: No, the woman puts that thing that they make like this...

cell.speaker: Antjie
cell.afr: Ahan,die vrou sit mos nou daai ding wat hulle so maak...

cell.speaker: Bab
cell.eng: Bab: A small skin that they make like this...

cell.speaker: Bab
cell.afr: n Velletjie wat hulle so maak...

cell.speaker: Bab
cell.eng: Bab: No, a small skin that they cut like this, then they sew buttons onto it, then

cell.speaker: Bab
cell.afr: Nee, ʼn velletjie wat hulle so sny, ja, dan werk hulle daar knope om, al al in die rondte, dan blom hulle hom nou so met die knope.

cell.speaker: Antjie
cell.eng: Antjie: A man puts the bat eared fox skin on.
cell.speaker: Bab

cell.notes: N|uu transcribed and translated by Ouma Geelmeid, Griet, Ouma Anna Koper, Claudia and Kerry. Bonny updated some; note: Mats Exter has 'skin' with a short vowel but it sounds long here to me.

cell.speaker: Antjie
cell.eng: Antjie:No! Then he puts it on his head.

cell.notes: N|uu Levi transcribed and translated. Bonny updated. Alena updated. N|uu transcribed and

translated by Ouma Geelmeid, Griet, Ouma Anna Koper, Claudia and Kerry.

cell.speaker: Bab
cell.eng: Bab: The skin of a wild cat.

cell.speaker: Antjie
cell.eng: Antjie: The man puts on the skin of bat eared foxHe puts it on his head.

cell.speaker: Antjie
cell.nuu: A ǂo ha !ai ||q ||’aa ûu, ha !ai || ha n|aa.

cell.notes: N|uu Levi transcribed and translated. Bonny updated.

cell.speaker: Tony
cell.eng: OS (Tony): So yes, it’s the skin of a cat.

cell.speaker: Tony
cell.afr: So ja, dis ʼn kat se vel.

cell.speaker: Bab
cell.eng: Bab: She puts it on her head.

cell.notes: N|uu Kerry transcribed and translated
N|uu Kerry transcribed and translated
N|uu Kerry transcribed and translated
N|uu Levi transcribed and translated

cell.speaker: Antjie
cell.eng: Antjie: This now means a cat’s skin, “

cell.speaker: Antjie
cell.afr: Dis nou gebedoel ʼn kat se vel,

cell.notes: N|uu Kerry transcribed and translated

cell.speaker: Tony
cell.eng: OS (Tony): And what about the little horn the men put here?

cell.speaker: Tony
cell.afr: En wat van die horinkie wat die manne hier gesit het?

cell.notes: N|uu Kerry transcribed and translated

cell.speaker: Bab
cell.eng: Bab: The horn of a steenbok.

cell.notes: N|uu Levi transcribed and translated

cell.speaker: Antjie
cell.eng: Antjie: Look at it here! It is the assegai. It is the assegai
OS: Now who was Agarob? Agarob was his name.

cell.speaker: Antjie
cell.nuu: |a ke a ha, nǂuna ǂoo. Nǂuna ǂoo ke a ha.
cell.afr: Nou wie was Agarob gewees? Agarob was sy naam gewees.

cell.notes: N|uu Levi transcribed and translated. Bonny updated. Nǂuna ǂoo ~ nǂona ǂoo.

cell.speaker: Girl at back
cell.eng: Girl at back: No, but they’re not speaking Nama

cell.speaker: Meisie agter
cell.afr: Nee, maar hulle praat nie Nama nie.

cell.notes: N|uu Kerry transcribed and translated

cell.speaker: Antjie
cell.eng: Antjie: He stands with the assegai.

cell.nuu: : Ku ca ku !’ana n|a nǂuna ǂoo.

cell.notes: N|uu Levi transcribed and translated. Bonny changed !’anna to !’ana.I assume it is pronounced as n!ana because it is intervocalic.

cell.speaker: Antjie
cell.eng: He stands here with his rifle,

cell.notes: Assegai= a spear. N|uu Kerry transcribed

cell.afr: geweer, met sy assegaai. Assegaai is nou

cell.notes: and translated N|uu Levi transcribed and translated. Note: alternate pronuciation nǂona ǂoo.

cell.speaker: Nigel
cell.eng: OS (Nigel): Can you show it to me.

cell.speaker: Nigel
cell.afr: Kan jy dit vir my wys.

cell.speaker: Nigel
cell.eng: OS (Nigel): Show it to me please. Show it so that I can see, yes that’s it.

cell.speaker: Nigel
cell.afr: Wys dit vir my asseblief. Wys dit sodat ek dit kan sien, ja daar’s hy.

cell.speaker: Nigel
cell.eng: OS (Nigel): So, tell me again what is on his head.

cell.speaker: Nigel
cell.afr: So, sê vir my weer wat is op sy kop.

cell.notes: N|uu Kerry transcribed and translated

cell.speaker: Tony
cell.eng: OS (Tony): What does he put on?

cell.notes: N|uu Kerry transcribed and translated

cell.speaker: Tony
cell.eng: OS (Tony): When you say that, does it mean the horn?

cell.speaker: Tony
cell.afr: As jy so sê dan noem jy die horing?

cell.speaker: Tony
cell.eng: OS (Tony): Is that other object not a (headpiece)?

cell.speaker: Tony
cell.afr: Is daai ander ding nie ʼnnie?

cell.speaker: Tony
cell.eng: OS (Tony): But they don’t pull it through the legs

cell.speaker: Tony
cell.afr: Maar hulle trek dit nie deur die bene nie.

cell.speaker: Bab
cell.eng: Bab: They’ve got it through the legs you can see.

cell.speaker: Bab
cell.afr: Hulle het hom deur die bene, jy kan mos sien.

cell.speaker: Antjie
cell.eng: Antjie: It must be pulled through the legs, this one is in front. This one is to protect, just like a small apron.

cell.speaker: Antjie
cell.afr: Hy moet deur die bene getrek word, hierdie ene is voor. Hierdie ene is net soos om te beskerm, net soos ʼn klein voorskootjie.

cell.notes: “Apron” in this instance is referring to a loincloth type item of clothing.

cell.speaker: Tony
cell.eng: OS (Tony): What do you call a small apron in Nama?

cell.speaker: Tony
cell.afr: Hoe noem julle ʼn klein voorskoot in Nama?

cell.speaker: Tony
cell.eng: OS (Tony): Tell us about the hair.What do they put on the head? What are these things on the head?

cell.speaker: Tony
cell.afr: Maar sê ons wat van die hare hier. Wat sit hulle op die kop? Wat is daardie goed op die kop?

cell.speaker: Bab
Antjie
cell.eng: Antjie:What kind of hair is that?
cell.speaker: Bab
Antjie
cell.eng: Antjie:What kind of hair is that?
cell.speaker: Bab
cell.eng: Bab: Ostrich. It looks as they are ostrich skins. It is true. Do look! It is ostrich.

cell.speaker: Bab
Bab
Antjie
Antjie
cell.nuu: ue. ue ûu. Kx’am ke. Kx’uu n|aa n|aa! ue.
cell.afr: Lyk vir my is die se

cell.notes: N|uu transcribed and translated by Ouma Geelmeid, Griet, Ouma Anna Koper, Claudia and Kerry. ‘|Hirosi’ /|qarusi/ was translated by Ouma Geelmeid as ‘duinbos’ in Afrikaans. ‘Duinbos is another name for ‘besembossie’ or ‘broom bush’, Crotalaria Spartioides. N|uu Levi transcribed and translated. Bonny updated. Alena updated.

cell.speaker: Bab
cell.eng: Bab: Ostrich. Looks to me like ostrich feathers.

cell.speaker: Bab
cell.afr: Volstruis. Lyk vir my dis volstruis, vere daai.

cell.speaker: Tony
cell.eng: OS (Tony): And what’s the word for it in your language?

cell.speaker: Tony
cell.afr: En hoenoem julle dit in die taal?

cell.notes: N|uu

cell.eng: used for the hair, they must have that skin.

cell.afr: wat hulle die hare van gemaak het, hulle moet die vel by had.

cell.speaker: Bab
cell.eng: Bab: Now this is theskin and the feathers.

cell.notes: N|uu Levi transcribed and translated. Bonny updated.

cell.speaker: Hendrik
cell.eng: OS (Hendrik): Now what do you call the skin?
cell.speaker: Antjie
Hendrik
Antjie
cell.afr: Nou wat noem julle die vel?

cell.notes: N|uu transcribed and translated by Ouma Geelmeid, Griet, Ouma Anna Koper, Claudia and Kerry.

cell.speaker: Bab
cell.eng: Bab: No it’s that very small loincloth with the beads.

cell.notes: N|uu transcribed and translated by Ouma Geelmeid, Griet, Ouma Anna Koper, Claudia and Kerry. !ae=small loincloth usualy worn by children that just overs your private parts. Bonny: I hear !gae, not !ae.
N|uu transcribed and translated by Ouma Geelmeid, Griet, Ouma Anna Koper, Claudia and Kerry.

cell.speaker: Antjie
cell.eng: Antjie: Yes, in the hair.Yes the skin and the feathers.

cell.speaker: Antjie
cell.afr: Ja, in die Ja, die vel en die vere.

cell.speaker: Tony
cell.eng: OS (Tony): And tell me what about those shoes they are wearing? What about those shoes?

cell.speaker: Tony
cell.afr: En sê vir my wat van die skoene wat hulle dra. Wat van daardie skoene?

cell.speaker: Antjie
cell.eng: Antjie: Look at the shoes […] Like Jesus’ shoes.
cell.speaker: Bab
cell.eng: Bab: Mmm, what do the shoes look like?
cell.speaker: Antjie
cell.eng: Antjie: They are not sandals that they take and put in? Bab: No, young one.
cell.speaker: Antjie
cell.eng: Antjie: (They) take the skin. Is it not the skin?
cell.speaker: Bab
cell.eng: Bab: Is it not the skin?
cell.speaker: Antjie
Bab
cell.eng: Bab: Let me look at it again.

cell.notes: Levi transcribed and translated. Bonny updated.
N|uu Levi transcribed and translated

cell.speaker: Bab
cell.afr: Jong kyk mooi, kyk mooi hier.

cell.speaker: Tony
cell.eng: OS (Tony): Are those genuine Bushman shoes?

cell.speaker: Tony
cell.eng: OS (Tony): It is beautiful raw hide-shoes

cell.speaker: Tony
cell.eng: OS (Tony): Those are just pieces of skin.

cell.speaker: Hendrik
cell.eng: Hendrik: When he kills the Gemsbok he simply keeps

cell.speaker: Hendrik
cell.afr: Kyk as hy mos nou die Gemsbok gegooi het, dan vat hy sommer daai vel…

cell.speaker: Bab
Hendrik
cell.eng: Hendrik: . . . that skin, and then he makes shoes with it, he’s not worried about tanning the skin.

cell.speaker: Bab
Hendrik
cell.afr: …daai vel, en dan maak hy vir hom daarmee skoene, hy’s nie geworried oor brei nie.

cell.notes: N|uu Levi transcribed and translated

cell.speaker: Tony
cell.eng: OS (Tony): What do you call these shoes in the Bushman language?

cell.speaker: Tony
cell.afr: Hoe noem julle die skoene in die Boesman taal.

cell.notes: N|uu Levi transcribed and translated

AFRIKAANS/KHOEKHOEGOWAB/N|UU TRANSCRIPTION
Kerry transcribed and translated

cell.speaker: Tony
cell.eng: OS (Tony): That’s for one shoe, what do they say for many?

cell.speaker: Tony
cell.afr: En as hulle, dis een skoen, en as hulle baie …?

cell.speaker: Antjie
cell.eng: Antjie: They are shoes. OS (Tony): Shoes.

cell.notes: N|uu Kerry transcribed and translated

cell.speaker: Bab
cell.eng: Bab: They have their shoes put on.

cell.speaker: Bab
cell.nuu: A na hn ka !u n a ǂasn.

cell.notes: N|uu Levi transcribed and translated

cell.speaker: Bab
cell.eng: Bab: Hand me my shoes so I can put them on.

cell.speaker: Bab
cell.afr: Gee my skoene dat ek aantrek.

cell.notes: N|uu Levi transcribed and translated

cell.speaker: Hendrik
cell.eng: OS (Hendrik): This is a duiker’s horn.

cell.speaker: Hendrik
cell.afr: Hiedie is die duiker se horing.

cell.notes: N|uu Kerry transcribed and translated

cell.speaker: Bab
cell.eng: Bab: No it’s a steenbok, the tip of the horn

cell.speaker: Bab
cell.eng: Bab: It doesn’t look like a duiker’s horn

cell.speaker: Bab
cell.afr: Hy lyk nie soos ʼn duiker se horing nie.

AFRIKAANS/KHOEKHOEGOWAB/N|UU TRANSCRIPTION

cell.speaker: Antjie
cell.eng: Antjie: It’s not the tip of a duiker’s horn, it’s a steenbok’s.

cell.speaker: Antjie
cell.afr: Dis nie ʼn duiker se voorpunt nie, dis ʼn steenbok s’n.
